text: Hi! Is it possible to unload a module? What I am trying to do is: I have a package that contains some physical constants (for example g, the acceleration of gravity). I provide units with the constants through `Unitful.jl`. But I want the user to be able to use the constants with units or without units.

elements.text: Hi! Is it possible to unload a module? What I am trying to do is: I have a package that contains some physical constants (for example g, the acceleration of gravity). I provide units with the constants through
. But I want the user to be able to use the constants with units or without units.

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

One option is to leave the user the burden of importing the module and defining all the unitless constants by hand at the beginning. But because my user is me, I found this annoying. What I thought is to have two submodules on my package. One contains the values with units and one without units.

```module MyPackage
    module WithUnits end
    module NoUnits end
end```
So that the user can do at the beginning:

```using MyPackage
using MyPackage.WithUnits```
and get the constants with units or without them at will.

This seems to work, but then how can I change my choice after I loaded all of them? This would be useful for example to run the unit tests with both of the choices.

What other design ideas come to mind?

This seems to work, but then how can I change my choice after I loaded all of them? This would be useful for example to run the unit tests with both of the choices.

What other design ideas come to mind?

text: You can't undefine bindings from Main, only bind them to something else.

elements.text: You can't undefine bindings from Main, only bind them to something else.

text: Hmmm. Thanks! This is probably not the wisest design. I will need to think more about it.
